questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with hypertension. After initial workup and investigations, he is started on captopril. Which of the following changes in renal function will reduce the blood pressure in this patient?

choices.text: Decreased sodium reabsorption in the distal tubule

questions.solution:
Among the given options, decreased sodium reabsorption in the distal tubule is one of the changes seen due to captopril.

Captopril is an ACE inhibitor. It decreases the levels of angiotensin II thereby decreasing all its physiological effects leading to:

  • Vasodilatation
  • Decreased salt and water reabsorption in the proximal tubules
  • Decreased stimulation of aldosterone which reduces sodium reabsorption in the distal tubules
  • Increased renin secretion due to reduced negative feedback.

Other options:

Option B: Angiotensin II receptors are blocked by ARBs like losartan.

Option C: ACE inhibitors increase renin secretion because the decrease in the levels of angiotensin II reduces the negative feedback on renin release.

Option D: Decreased angiotensin II improves renal blood flow.

questions.text: An elderly male patient presents to the hospital with a history of swelling of the legs for the past few months. During the examination, it is noted that the patient has bilateral pitting type of pedal edema, elevated jugular venous pressure, and enlarged liver. Auscultation reveals the presence of a third heart sound. This sound occurs due to

choices.text: Closure of the aortic and pulmonary valves
Vibrations in the ventricular wall during systole
Vibrations of the ventricular wall during diastole
Closure of mitral  and tricuspid valves

questions.solution:
Clinical features suggest heart failure which is one of the pathological causes of the third heart sound. The third heart sound is caused by vibrations of the ventricular wall during diastole.

A third heart sound is a weak rumbling sound heard at the beginning of the middle third of diastole. It is best heard with the bell of the stethoscope. It may be normally present in children, adolescents, and young adults. In older adults, it usually indicates systolic heart failure.

Important aspects of other heart sound

First heart sound is caused due to the closure of the mitral and tricuspid valves. It is a high-pitched sound best heard with the diaphragm of a stethoscope. The first heart sound due to mitral valve closure is best heard over the apex of the heart, and due to the closure of the tricuspid valve is best heard in the fourth intercostal space in the left sternal border.

The second heart sound is caused by the closure of the aortic (A2) and pulmonary valves (P2). It is a high-pitched sound best heard with the diaphragm of a stethoscope. A2 is best heard in the right second intercostal space, and P2 is best heard in the left second intercostal space. 

Fourth heart sound is caused due to late ventricular filling through active atrial contraction. It is a low-pitched sound, heard best through the bell of the stethoscope. When it originates from the left ventricular, S4 is best heard at the apex with the patient in the left lateral decubitus position at end-expiration. When it originates from the right ventricular, it is heard best at the left lower sternal border. It is seen in ventricular hypertrophy, ischemic heart disease, ventricular aneurysm, etc.

questions.text: The marked phase in the cardiac muscle action potential mainly occurs due to ______.
questions.solution:
The marked phase in the cardiac action potential is phase 3. It occurs due to the efflux of potassium ions.

Phases of the cardiac muscle action potential.

  • Phase 0 (depolarization): Opening of fast sodium channels. When the cardiac cell is stimulated, the fast sodium channels (voltage-gated sodium channels) open and cause sodium influx. This depolarizes the cell and the membrane potential becomes positive. It reaches about +20 mV. 
  • Phase 1 (initial repolarization): When the membrane potential reaches +20mV, the fast sodium channels close and the potassium channels open. The potassium ions leave the cell leading to a brief repolarisation. 
  • Phase 2 (plateau): Fast potassium channels close and calcium channels open. The voltage-gated Ca2+ channels start opening slowly in phases 0 and 1. The influx of calcium through these channels is balanced by the decrease in the efflux of potassium via the potassium channels. This produces the plateau. 
  • Phase 3 (rapid repolarization): Slow potassium channels open and calcium channels close. The potassium ions leave the cell through slow potassium channels and the calcium channels close, stopping the influx of calcium ions. This ends the plateau and brings the membrane potential to the resting level. 
  • Phase 4 (resting membrane potential):  around −80 to −90 millivolts.

The illustration given below shows action potential of cardiac muscle.

Differences in the cardiac and the skeletal muscles - The action potentials of the skeletal muscle are almost entirely caused by the sudden opening of large numbers of fast sodium channels. In cardiac muscle, it is mainly caused by fast sodium channels and L-type calcium channels (slow calcium channels).

questions.text:
A mother brings her baby with complaints of decreased movements for the past 2 months. On examination, the child appeared floppy. Which of the following features if present, makes spinal muscular atrophy as the likely diagnosis?
  1. Spasticity
  2. Exaggerated reflexes
  3. Flaccidity
  4. Tongue fasciculations
  5. Hypotonia
questions.solution:
Spinal muscular atrophy is a type of lower motor neuron lesion. Therefore, the baby will have flaccidity, tongue fasciculations, and hypotonia.

In spinal muscular atrophy, there is a mutation of the SMN1 gene which results in the degeneration of lower motor neurons. The affected patient will have symmetric weakness, flaccid paralysis, fasciculations, hyporeflexia, and muscle atrophy. 

Lower motor neurons are the neurons whose axons terminate on the skeletal muscles. Damage to these neurons will lead to 

  • flaccid paralysis
  • muscular atrophy
  • fasciculations- visible muscle twitches that appear as flickers under the skin
  • hypotonia- decreased muscle tone
  • hyporeflexia or areflexia.

Important examples of lower motor neuron lesions are poliomyelitis, spinal muscular atrophy, and Bell's palsy.

Upper motor neurons typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor neurons and brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons. Lesions to these neurons lead to:

  • spasticity 
  • hypertonia
  • hyperactive stretch reflex 
  • positive Babinski sign
  • clonus

Important examples of upper motor neuron lesions are stroke and primary lateral sclerosis.

Babinski sign- The Babinski sign is a dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of the other toes when the lateral aspect of the sole of the foot is scratched. The normal response is the plantar flexion in all toes. 

Mechanism- It is based on the principle that stimulation of the S1 dermatome stimulates the S1 myotome that is responsible for the plantar flexion. Whenever the corticospinal tract is damaged the stimulation also spreads to the L4 and L5 myotomes, resulting in the contraction of toe extensors like extensor hallucis longus and extensor digitorum longus.

Below image shows Babinski's sign

In infants whose corticospinal tracts are not well developed, dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of the other toes is the natural response to stimuli applied to the sole of the foot.

The image below shows a normal response in an infant.

questions.text: You are monitoring a 45-year-old female patient in the postoperative ward. Her 24-hour urine output is 1.5 mL/min, serum creatinine is 1.0 mg/dL, and urine creatinine is 60 mg/dL. What is the patient's creatinine clearance rate?
questions.solution:
The creatinine clearance in this patient is 90 mL/min.

Creatinine clearance is defined as the volume of plasma from which creatinine is completely removed by the kidney in a given amount of time (usually minutes).

The formula used to calculate creatinine clearance (CCr) is:

 UCr × V ⁄ PCr  where,

UCr - Urine creatinine (mg/dL)

PCr - Serum creatinine (mg/dL)

V - Urine volume (mL/min)

Note: The creatinine clearance is usually expressed in mL/min; hence, the preferred unit of urine volume is mL/min, which is calculated based on the 24-hour urine volume. While calculating, ensure that both the urine creatinine and serum creatinine have the same units (either mg/dL or mg/mL).

In the given question,

UCr = 60 mg/dL

PCr = 1.0 mg/dL

V  = 1.5 mL/min

Substituting the values given in the question, we get:

Creatinine clearance =  UCr × V ⁄ PCr ,

= (60 x 1.5)/1

= 60 x 1.5

= 90 mL/min

Creatinine is a by-product of muscle metabolism and is cleared from the body fluids almost entirely by glomerular filtration. Therefore, the clearance of creatinine is used to assess GFR.

questions.text: A physiologist studies a chemoreceptor that detects elevated sodium levels and decreases the glomerular filtration rate. In the given image of the juxtaglomerular apparatus, which of the marked structures represents this chemoreceptor?
questions.solution:
The chemoreceptors that detect elevated sodium and decrease the glomerular filtration rate are the macula densa cells in the distal convoluted tubule. These are marked as '1' in the given illustration.

Macula densa cells are chemoreceptors that detect sodium and chloride concentrations of the tubular fluid. In response to elevated sodium and chloride, the macula densa cells trigger the contraction of the afferent arteriole, resulting in decreased flow of blood to the glomerulus and reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR). This vasoconstriction is mediated via increased sodium-potassium ATPase activity leading to increased adenosine formation resulting in calcium release. 

The given illustration shows:

1- Macula densa: These are specialized cells at the start of the distal convoluted tubule form the macula densa. 

2- Granular cells/JG cells: These are modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole; these are mechanoreceptors that secrete renin in response to a fall in blood pressure, which in turn, increases the blood pressure. 

3- Lacis cells: These are extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole. 

4- Proximal tubular cells: These are involved in sustaining glomerulotubular balance, a mechanism by which the percentage of the reabsorbed solutes is maintained at constant levels. This is achieved by increasing the reabsorption of the solutes and water in the proximal convoluted tubule in response to increased GFR.

questions.text: The following image shows the sequence of propulsion of a bolus in the gut by means of peristalsis. Which of the following substances is responsible for the configuration of the segment of the gut marked as '2'?
questions.solution:
The given configuration of the segment marked by '2' is due to the vasoactive intestinal peptide being responsible for a state of relaxation of this part of the gut. 

The above image shows peristalsis. It is a reflex response that is initiated when the gut wall is stretched by the contents of the lumen. The given segment of relaxation is an anterograde segment that moves from an oral to a caudal direction. 

Stretching of the gut wall releases serotonin and activates the cholinergic neurons present in the myenteric plexus. Cholinergic neurons passing in an anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus. Cholinergic neurons passing in a retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which cause contraction of a segment of the intestine behind the bolus.

The following image shows the events as described.

Note:

In achalasia cardia, there is a defective release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus.

questions.text: "Vasopressin escape" in SIADH results due to:
questions.solution:
Vasopressin escape in SIADH (Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion) results due to downregulation of aquaporin 2 production.

Prolonged exposure to elevated levels of vasopressin (ADH) leads eventually to downregulation of aquaporin-2 receptors. This prevents excessive reabsorption of water, despite high serum ADH levels and hence maintains euvolemia. This is known as vasopressin escape. This helps prevent excessive dilutional hyponatremia in SIADH.

questions.text: How are magnitude of stimulus felt and intensity of stimulus applied related according to the Weber-Fechner law?
questions.solution:
According to the Weber-Fechner law, the magnitude of sensation felt is directly proportional to the logarithm of the applied stimulus intensity.

Other important laws in neurophysiology:

  • Bell Magendie law- The anterior or ventral roots of the spinal nerves are motor and the posterior or dorsal nerve roots are sensory.
  • Law of projection- Stimulation of a sensory system at any point central to sensory organs produces a sensation that is projected at the periphery and not at the point of stimulation.

questions.text: The test below determines the blood group of an individual. Choose the correct statement about it.

choices.text: Contains transferases for N-acetylgalactosamine and galactose

questions.solution:
Based on the agglutination test shown in the image, the blood group is O positive, since there is no agglutination with 'A' and 'B' agglutinins, and agglutination is seen with anti-Rh. O positive blood group contains the gene for a fucose transferase, resulting in persistence of the H antigen.

Individuals with A blood group have the A antigen, B blood group have the B antigen, blood group AB has both, and blood group O has neither of them. All individuals have the H gene that encodes fucose transferase. It forms an H antigen by adding a terminal fucose. Individuals with blood group A contain a transferase that attaches N-acetylgalactosamine to the terminal part of the H antigen. Individuals with blood group B contain a transferase that attaches a terminal galactose to the H antigen. Individuals AB blood group have both transferases, while individuals with O blood group have neither. Therefore, H antigen persists in O blood group individuals. 

Bombay blood group is a rare blood group, which was first discovered in Bombay. In this, there is an absence of the H antigen on the red blood cell membrane. Absence of H antigen results in absence of A and B antigens. Their plasma contains anti-A, anti-B, and strong anti-H antibodies. Since their red cells do not react with anti-A, anti-B, and anti-AB antiserums, they can be recognized as the O blood group in cell typing. However, the O blood group has an H antigen. The anti-H antibodies present in a patient with Bombay blood group can react with H antigen present in O blood group leading to fatal transfusion reactions. Therefore, patients with Bombay blood group require the same blood group during transfusion.

The human red blood cell membrane contains certain blood group antigens or agglutinogens. They are inherited as Mendelian dominant and individuals are divided into 4 blood groups. Antibodies against the red cell agglutinogens are called agglutinins. They are usually IgG or IgM immunoglobulins.

ABO blood typing is performed by mixing the individual's red blood cells with antisera that contains the various agglutinins on a slide, and observing for the presence of clumping or agglutination.

questions.text: While measuring the blood pressure of an 80-year-old man, it was found that the pulse pressure was wide. Assuming he has no other co-morbidities, and that it is due to age-related changes, what is the physiology behind this widened pulse pressure?
questions.solution:
Pulse pressure increases with age due to decreased arterial wall compliance. 

Diastolic blood pressure falls after 60 years of age due to increased arterial stiffness and decreased compliance, often associated with arteriosclerosis. As the left ventricle contracts against stiffer, less compliant arteries, systolic blood pressure also increases. 

As a result of these two changes, pulse pressure increases (↑PP = ↑SBP - ↓DBP) 

The factors that affect the pulse pressure:

  • the stroke volume output of the heart 
  • the compliance or total distensibility of the arterial walls
  • the character of ejection from the heart during systole (less important)

Pulse pressure = Stroke volume/ arterial compliance

Widened pulse pressure (> 40 mm Hg) occurs with several diseases such as:

  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Aortic sclerosis
  • Severe iron deficiency anemia 
  • Arteriosclerosis 
  • Hyperthyroidism 

In the majority of these cases, systolic pressures increase while diastolic pressures remain near normal.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of cholecystokinin?

choices.text: Relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi

questions.solution:
Cholecystokinin(CCK) inhibits gastric emptying, it does not stimulate it.

CCK is secreted by I cells in the mucosa of the upper small intestine. It is also found in nerves in the distal ileum and colon, and neurons in the cerebral cortex. Its functions include:

  • Stimulation of pancreatic enzyme secretion (option A)
  • Gallbladder contraction
  • Relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi to allow the flow of bile and pancreatic juice into the intestinal lumen (option D)
  • Inhibits gastric emptying
  • Increases the synthesis of enterokinase
  • Enhances the motility of the small intestine and colon (option C)
  • Increases the action of secretin, alkalizing the pancreatic juice
  • Trophic effect on the pancreas

The secretion of CCK is increased by:

  • Products of digestion like peptides and amino acids coming in contact with the intestinal mucosa
  • Presence of fatty acids containing >10 C atoms in the duodenum
  • CCK-releasing peptide and monitor peptide

Bile and pancreatic juice enter the duodenum in response to CCK, enhancing the digestion of protein and fat. The products of this digestion stimulate further CCK secretion, as positive feedback. However, this positive feedback is terminated when the products of digestion move further down the GI tract.

Stimulates H+ secretion by activating H2 receptors on the parietal cell membrane.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about the skeletal muscle contraction?
  1. Extracellular Ca2+ is not important for contraction
  2. Ca2+ is released from mitochondria
  3. Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
  4. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on sarcolemma have no role in excitation-contraction coupling
questions.solution:
During the contraction of the skeletal muscle, the Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Only statement 3 is correct.

Excitation-contraction coupling refers to the process by which the membrane depolarization of the muscle fiber (excitation) leads to the contraction of the muscle.

The steps of excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle are as follows:

  • Motor-neuron discharge causes the release of acetylcholine at the motor endplate, which binds to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.
  • This causes increased Na+ and K+ conductance in the endplate membrane, leading to the generation of end-plate potential, which is a local potential.
  • When the local endplate potential reaches a threshold for the muscle fiber, an action potential is generated.
  • The generated action potential passes inward through the T tubules, leading to the spread of depolarisation.
  • The depolarization of the muscle fiber causes the release of Ca2+ from terminal cisterns of the sarcoplasmic reticulum and diffusion to thick and thin filaments.
  • The calcium released, binds to troponin C, uncovering myosin-binding sites on actin.
  • The formation of cross-linkages between actin and myosin and sliding of thin on thick filaments causes contraction of the skeletal muscle.

Steps in relaxation:

  • The cytoplasmic calcium is pumped back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, by the action of SERCA (sarcoplasmic endoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase).
  • Once the calcium concentration is lowered, the interaction between actin and myosin ceases, and the muscle relaxes. 
Other options:
 
Statement 1: Incorrect - Extracellular calcium levels play an important role in muscle contraction. When there is a decrease in extracellular calcium as in hypocalcemia, the voltage-gated sodium channels are activated, which causes sodium influx. The increased intracellular sodium concentration causes sustained depolarization, which may lead to tetany.
 
Statement 2: Incorrect - Ca2+ is not released from mitochondria. It is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
 
Statement 4: Voltage-gated calcium channels on the sarcoplasmic reticulum are activated by a depolarizing stimulus, which causes the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. The increased calcium concentration will eventually lead to muscle contraction.

questions.text: During research on male contraceptives, a group of scientists was studying the blood-testis barrier.  This barrier is located between:
questions.solution:
The blood-testis barrier is located between Sertoli cells and Sertoli cells.

Sertoli cells are linked by tight junctions, the strongest intercellular barrier in the body. This arrangement forms the blood-testes barrier.

Important functions of the blood testes barrier are:

  • It prevents the passing of large molecules from interstitial tissue and basal compartment to the tubular lumen.
  • It helps in maintaining the composition of the tubular fluid.
  • It protects the developing sperms from immunological attack and blood borne noxious agents.

questions.text: A child who was trying to lift a heavy weight suddenly drops it due to muscle relaxation. Which of the following is true about this reflex?

choices.text: Monosynaptic reflex having Golgi tendon organ as receptor
Disynaptic reflex having Golgi tendon organ as receptor
Monosynaptic reflex having muscle spindle as receptor
Disynaptic reflex having muscle spindle as receptor

questions.solution:
The given scenario is an example of an inverse stretch reflex and it is a disynaptic reflex having the Golgi tendon organ as a receptor.

Up to a physiological limit, the harder a muscle is stretched, the stronger the contraction. However, when the tension becomes too great and can cause damage to the muscle fibers, the contraction suddenly stops and the muscle relaxes. This is known as the inverse stretch reflex. 

The receptor for the inverse stretch reflex is the Golgi tendon organ. It lies in series with the muscle fibers and is stimulated by passive stretch and active contraction of the muscle, but mainly the latter. The Golgi tendon organ is innervated by type Ib sensory fibers. These fibers synapse with an inhibitory interneuron which terminates on the motor neuron innervating the same muscle. The inverse stretch reflex is thus disynaptic. Stimulation of the Golgi tendon organ brings about the relaxation of the muscle.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about chemical synapses?
questions.solution:
Unidirectional conduction is a feature of chemical synapses. 

There are two types of synapses:

Chemical synapse:

The first neuron secretes a neurotransmitter at its nerve ending synapse, which acts on receptors of the next neuron to excite, inhibit, or modify its sensitivity. Conduction is unidirectional (one-way conduction). This one-way signal ensures that the signal is directed towards a specific goal. A synaptic cleft of 200-300 Å or 20-30nm separates the neurons.  The presynaptic membrane contains transmitter vesicles that contain the neurotransmitter. It does not have gap junctions. Examples of neurotransmitters is acetylcholine, norepinephrine, epinephrine, histamine, gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA), and glycine. 

Electrical synapse:

The cytoplasms of adjacent cells are directly connected by clusters of ion channels called gap junction channels. There is free movement of ions from one cell to the next cell. The conduction is bidirectional and the intercellular gap is 20-40Å or 2-4nm. The bidirectional transmission of electrical synapses permits them to coordinate the activities of large groups of interconnected neurons. Electrical synapses are present in the cardiac uscles and visceral smooth muscles.

The net force-producing fluid movement across the capillary wall is 12 mm Hg out of the capillary.

The net force across the capillary wall can be calculated by

= (Pressure at the arteriolar end- interstitial hydrostatic pressure)- (capillary osmotic pressure-interstitial osmotic pressure)

= (36-0)-(25-1)

= 36-24

The rate of filtration at any point along a capillary depends on a balance of forces sometimes termed Starling forces.

The two main forces are hydrostatic pressure and osmotic pressure. The hydrostatic pressure gradient is calculated by subtracting the hydrostatic pressure of the interstitial fluid from the hydrostatic pressure in the capillary. The interstitial fluid pressure varies from one organ to another. It is positive in the liver and kidneys and as high as 6 mm Hg in the brain.

The other force is the osmotic pressure across the capillary wall. This component is directed inward. Osmotic pressure gradient is calculated by subtracting the colloid osmotic pressure of the interstitial fluid from the colloid osmotic pressure of plasma. Colloidal osmotic pressure is exerted by the plasma proteins in the capillaries.

questions.text: A patient who had previously been intubated while admitted to the intensive care unit was found to have tracheal stenosis during his follow-up visits. Which of the following graphs would represent the flow-volume loop in this patient?
questions.solution:
The graph representing the flow-volume loop in this patient with tracheal stenosis would be graph 3, or option C. 

When there is fixed central airway obstruction, there is obstruction and limitation of airflow during both inspiration and expiration. This leads to the flattening of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs of the flow-volume loop, as observed in tracheal stenosis.

Other options:

Option A: Image 1 shows airflow limitation and flattening in the inspiratory limb of the loop. It is seen in conditions responsible for variable upper airway obstruction like vocal fold paralysis, and extrathoracic tracheomalacia.

Option B: Image 2 shows airflow limitation and flattening in the expiratory limb of the loop. This is seen in conditions responsible for variable lower airway obstruction like tracheomalacia of intrathoracic airway or bronchogenic cysts.

Option D: Image 4 shows a concave upward, pattern in the expiratory limb. This is also a called "scooped-out" or "coved" pattern and is observed in cases responsible for airflow obstruction at any transmural pressure, like in asthma or chronic bronchitis.

A sawtooth pattern of the loop consists of small, rapid oscillations in airflow during both expiration and inspiration. It is seen in neuromuscular diseases, Parkinson's disease, laryngeal dyskinesia, pedunculated tumours of the upper airway, tracheobronchomalacia, and obstructive sleep apnea.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Insulin-like growth factor-1(IGF-1)?

choices.text: It is synthesized in the liver
It has a major role in fetal development
It is also synthesized by bone
It’s secretion is regulated by growth hormone levels

questions.solution:
IGF -2 has a major role in growth during fetal development, while IGF-1 plays a major role in skeletal and cartilage growth.

Insulin-like growth factors (IGF) are the polypeptide growth factors that are similar to insulin in their structures. They are also called somatomedins. IGFs that are found in human beings are IGF-1 and IGF-2.

IGF -1 is also called somatomedin C. It is synthesized by the liver and other peripheral tissues like bone. Secretion is independent of growth hormone before birth, however, after birth, the growth hormone stimulates the secretion of IGF-1. The major physiological role of IGF-1 is to stimulate skeletal and cartilage growth. Its plasma concentration rises during childhood, peaks during puberty, and declines during old age.

IGF-2 secretion is independent of the growth hormone levels. It has a major role in the growth of fetus before birth.

questions.text: All of the following can be associated with hyperkalemia, except ____.
questions.solution:
Epinephrine will cause the shift of potassium back into the cell, hence cannot be associated with hyperkalemia.

Factors that shift potassium into the cells, thereby decreasing the extracellular K+ concentration, leading to hypokalemia are:

  • Increased insulin and aldosterone secretion
  • β-adrenergic stimulation (eg: epinephrine)
  • Alkalosis

Factors that shift potassium out of the cells, thereby increasing the extracellular K+ concentration, leading to hyperkalemia are:

  • Insulin deficiency
  • Aldosterone deficiency (Addison's disease)
  • β-adrenergic blockade
  • Acidosis
  • Cell lysis in severe muscle injury or red blood cell lysis
  • Strenuous exercise
  • Increased extracellular fluid osmolarity

Epinephrine is an agonist at alpha 1, beta 1, and beta 2 receptors.

The β actions are mediated through cAMP. Epinephrine binds to Gs → ATP and is broken down to cAMP by the enzyme adenylyl cyclase. This results in:

  • In the liver and muscle- hyperglycemia and hypokalaemia due to potassium uptake in muscle and liver
  • In adipose tissue- increased plasma free fatty acids
  • In the heart- an increased force of contraction reinforces the positive inotropic action
  • In pancreatic islets- increases glucagon secretion

Epinephrine is used in anaphylaxis, to prolong the action of local anesthetics, cardiac arrest, and as inhalational epinephrine in the treatment of post-intubation and infectious croup.

Epinephrine is contraindicated in anesthesia with halothane due to the risk of arrhythmias and in patients receiving beta-blockers because the marked rise in BP can occur due to unopposed alpha action.

questions.text: The following image shows the reabsorption and secretion of various ions. In which part of the nephron is this seen?

choices.text: Descending limb of the loop of Henle
Ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
The given image shows a portion of the late distal convoluted tubule. This can be identified by the following features represented in the diagram:

  • Presence of two distinct types of cells, the principal cells, and intercalated cells.
  • The principal cells are identified by the reabsorption of sodium and secretion of potassium into the lumen.
  • The intercalated cells are identified by the absorption of potassium with the secretion of hydrogen ions into the lumen.
  • Presence of water absorption in the presence of anti-diuretic hormone (ADH)

Note that these features are also seen in the collecting duct. The late distal tubule and collecting duct are similar anatomically and functionally.

In the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), sodium, water, and chloride are mainly reabsorbed here along with glucose, amino acids, and other solutes. The total solute concentration or osmolarity remains the same all along the proximal tubule due to the high permeability to water.

The thin descending limb of the loop of Henle is permeable to water, urea, and sodium. The tubular fluid becomes hypertonic in this segment. The thick ascending limb reabsorbs Na+, K+, and Cl- by a Na+-K+-2Cl- co-transporter. Some of the K+ that is reabsorbed leaks back into the lumen, creating a potential difference with more positivity in the lumen. This lumen positivity is responsible for the absorption of divalent ions like Ca+2 and Mg+2. The thick ascending limb is virtually impermeable to water. Since some of the solutes are reabsorbed and water is not reabsorbed, it dilutes the tubular fluid.

Early distal convoluted tubule (DCT) reabsorbs Na+ and Cl- by the Na+-Cl- co-transporter. This segment is also impermeable to water. Because of the relative solute reabsorption, there is dilution of the tubular fluid.

The late distal tubule and collecting duct have two kinds of cells as mentioned above. Principal cells reabsorb Na+ and secrete K+ into the lumen. The Na+ reabsorption is through epithelial Na+ channels (ENaC). The expression of ENaC is mediated by aldosterone and thus increases whenever there is activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. The absorption of Na+ is balanced by the secretion of K+ into the lumen.

The water permeability of the principal cells is controlled by ADH. When ADH levels are high, aquaporin 2 channels are inserted in the luminal membrane of the principal cells, leading to water reabsorption.

Intercalated cells reabsorb K+ and secrete H+ by an H+-K+ counter-transporter. They also have an H+ pump which is responsible for acid secretion.

questions.text: Somatosensory area has the largest representation for_____
questions.solution:
Somatosensory area has the largest representation for lips. 

The relative sizes of the cortical receiving areas of the sensory homunculus are proportionate to the use of the part. The sizes of these areas are directly proportional to the number of specialized sensory receptors in each respective peripheral area of the body.

Some body parts are represented by large areas in the somatic cortex—the lips the greatest of all, followed by the face and thumb, whereas the trunk and lower part of the body are represented by relatively small areas.

questions.text: After hitting your elbow against the wall, rubbing the affected area seems to relieve the pain. The stimulation of which of the following fibers is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The pain relief experienced after rubbing the affected area is due to the stimulation of Aβ sensory fibers.

The stimulation of large-type Aβ sensory fibers from peripheral tactile receptors depresses pain signal transmission from the same body area. This occurs due to local lateral inhibition in the spinal cord.

The activity of these cutaneous mechanosensitive afferents may reduce the responsiveness of dorsal horn neurons to the nociceptive input from afferent terminals. It explains why rubbing the skin near painful areas offers pain relief, and also explains why the local application of liniments relieves pain.

This is called the gate-control mechanism of pain modulation. It is the principle behind the use of transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) for pain relief. TENS uses electrodes to activate Aα and Aβ fibers near the injury.

Note:
Pain stimulus is transmitted by Aδ (fast pain) and C fibers (slow pain).

questions.text: A 72-year old man presented with complaints of reduced vision in the right eye. Kinetic perimetry revealed right homonymous hemianopia. What is the most likely location of the defect in the optic pathway?
questions.solution:
The most likely defect in this patient presenting with right homonymous hemianopia is in the left optic tract. Homonymous hemianopia involves a loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes.

Other options:

Option A - A lesion affecting the optic chiasma produces heteronymous hemianopia. It involves loss of vision on the opposite sides of visual fields in both eyes. 

Options C and D - Lesions of the retina and optic nerve affect the visual field of only that eye. The visual field of the opposite eye is normal. 

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Feedback uptake of surfactant by type II alveolar epithelial cells is regulated by
questions.solution:
Feedback uptake of surfactant by the type II alveo­lar epithelial cell is regulated by surfactant protein type A.

Surfactant:

It is the fluid lining the alveoli. It is produced by type 2 pneumocytes. It is mainly made up of phospholipids and proteins. The majority of the phospholipid is phosphatidylcholine. The second most abundant phospholipid is phosphatidylglycerol (PG). 

The important surfactant proteins (SP) present in the surfactant are:

  • SP-A is a large glycoprotein with a collagen-like domain. It regu­lates the feedback uptake of surfactant by the type II alveo­lar epithelial cells that secrete it.
  • SP-B and SP-C are smaller proteins. They form the film of the surfactant.
  • SP-D is a glycoprotein. It plays an important role in the organization of SP-B and SP-C into the surfactant layer.

The important function of the surface is to reduce surface tension. The pressure required for the expansion of alveoli is directly proportional to the surface tension present over the alveolar sacs. Surfactant reduces this surface tension and thereby reduces the pressure required to expand lungs. It also prevents pulmonary edema.

Clinical correlate- Surfactant production starts around 20 weeks of life and peaks at 35 weeks gestation. Deficiency of surfactant leads to respiratory distress syndrome. This is common in preterm infants.

questions.text: An elderly female patient presents to the hospital with complaints of increased tiredness and breathlessness. She is unable to do her day-to-day work. On examination, her conjunctiva appears pale. Laboratory investigations reveal a hemoglobin value of 7 g/dL. Which of the following curves represents the oxygen dissociation curve in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient has hemoglobin of 7g/dL. The curve that represents the oxygen dissociation curve in this patient is curve D.

In anemic hypoxia, the blood oxygen content is decreased. This is denoted by curve D. The patients might not experience any difficulty during rest because 2,3-DPG increases in the red blood cells. However, they may have difficulty during exercise because of a limited ability to increase O2 delivery to the active tissues. 

Conditions that cause a right shift in the oxygen hemoglobin curve are: (Conditions with the increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia
  • Hypercarbia
  • Decreased pH
  • Increased temperature
  • Increased 2,3-biphosphoglycerate

Conditions that cause a left shift in the oxygen hemoglobin curve 

  • Increased oxygen
  • Decreased carbon dioxide
  • Increased pH
  • Decreased temperature
  • Decreased 2,3-biphosphoglycerate
  • Fetal hemoglobin

Curve B represents the normal oxygen hemoglobin curve

Curve C represents oxygen with hemoglobin with 50% carboxyhemoglobin. CO is toxic because it reacts with hemoglobin to form carbonmonoxyhemoglobin (carboxyhemoglobin, COHb), and COHb does not take up O2. The affinity of hemoglobin for CO is 210 times its affinity for O2. Therefore, the hemoglobin bound to oxygen is decreased, and the oxygen dissociation curve of the remaining HbO2 shifts to the left.

questions.text: A patient presents with hypertension, moon facies, and easy bruisability. On examination, the following finding is noticed over the abdomen. His laboratory reports indicate excessive secretion of a specific adrenal hormone. This hormone is physiologically elevated in all of the following conditions, except ____.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a patient with hypertension, moon facies, easy bruisability, and multiple purple striae over the abdomen is consistent with Cushing's syndrome. The adrenal hormone implicated is cortisol and cortisol levels are physiologically elevated around early morning while waking up.

Cushing's syndrome can be ACTH-dependent and ACTH-independent. When it is caused by an adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) secreting tumor of the pituitary gland, it is called Cushing's disease. 

ACTH is a hormone secreted by the anterior pituitary gland. Its secretion is controlled by corticotropin-releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. In turn, ACTH stimulates the adrenal cortex to produce cortisol.

The image given below shows clinical features seen in Cushing syndrome.

The rate of secretion and levels of cortisol are high in the morning but low in the evening. Specifically, its levels are the highest about an hour before waking up in the morning and lowest around midnight. This occurs due to a cyclical alteration in the signals from the hypothalamus, over 24 hours.

Additionally, during a mentally stressful state and when pain causes physical stress, there is an increase in cortisol levels in the body.

The diurnal variation of cortisol production is shown in the image below.

    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)

    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors

      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

These include two steps:

  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value

  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the bradycardia seen in Cushing reflex?
questions.solution:
The bradycardia seen in the Cushing reflex is caused by baroreceptor activation in response to a raised arterial blood pressure.

The Cushing reflex is a triad of raised arterial blood pressure, bradycardia, and irregular respiration caused by raised intracranial pressure (ICP). Raised ICP compromises blood flow to the brain and activates the rostral ventrolateral medulla with an increase in arterial blood pressure. The increased arterial pressure maintains cerebral perfusion and activates the baroreceptor reflex that causes bradycardia.

The irregular respiration seen in the Cushing reflex is caused by inadequate blood flow and increased pressure on the brainstem.

Bainbridge reflex: It refers to the increase in the heart rate when the atrium is stretched. Whenever there is a stretch of the atrium, the stretch receptors are activated. They transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase the heart rate and strength of heart contraction. This reflex prevents the accumulation of blood in the atria, veins, and pulmonary circulation.

J reflex: C fiber-endings close to the pulmonary vessels are called J (juxtacapillary) receptors. These receptors are stimulated by hyperinflation of the lungs or intravenous administration of capsaicin. The reflex produced is apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension. 

Bezold Jarisch reflex (Coronary chemoreflex): Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region (eg, juxtacapillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) causes profound bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This is called the Bezold Jarisch reflex and can be elicited by capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, and veratridine. It can also be activated during myocardial infarction and on exposure to radioactive dyes during coronary angiography.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is secreted by the zona glomerulosa?
questions.solution:
The zona glomerulosa secretes aldosterone.

The adrenal cortex has three zones. From outer to inner, they are:

  • Zona glomerulosa: Secretes mineralocorticoids (Aldosterone)
  • Zona fasiculata: Secretes glucocorticoids (Cortisol and corticosterone)
  • Zona reticularis: Secretes sex steroids (dehydroepiandrosterone, androstenedione, estrogens, and glucocorticoids)

The adrenal medulla secretes catecholamines.

questions.text: The principal neurotransmitter in type I (Glomus) cells of the carotid body is:
questions.solution:
The principal neurotransmitter in type I (Glomus) cells of the carotid body is dopamine. 

Carotid and aortic bodies contain type I cells/Glomus cells and type II cells. Like adrenal chromaffin cells, they contain dense-core granules containing catecholamines. They are excited in a hypoxic state and their principal transmitter is dopamine which stimulates the nerve endings via D2 receptors.

questions.text:
The image below shows the effect of various factors on the levels of a hormone. Identify the correct statements regarding the hormone.
  1. It is regulated by GHRH and ghrelin.
  2. Its action on sodium is mediated by IGF-1.
  3. It can be suppressed by the administration of oral glucose.
  4. Its secretion decreases after a protein meal.
  5. Its secretion is increased by ghrelin.
questions.solution:
The hormone depicted in the graph shows pulsatile secretion, with an increase during strenuous exercise and early period of sleep, indicating that it is the growth hormone (GH). The correct statements regarding GH are 1, 3, and 5 (option B).

Growth hormone is secreted from the somatotropes located in the anterior pituitary. Its main role is the growth of the human body.

The levels of growth hormones show diurnal variation as well as variation across different age groups. Adolescents have the highest circulating levels of growth hormone, followed by children and adults. The levels are relatively low during the day and the pulsatile release of this hormone occurs during sleep.

Important regulators of growth hormone:

  • Growth hormone-releasing hormone- stimulates the production of the hormone
  • Somatostatin- inhibits the release of GH
  • Ghrelin- increases the GH release

Stimuli that increase GH secretion:

  • Hypoglycemia, deoxyglucose, fasting
  • Exercise
  • Protein meal, infusion of arginine
  • Glucagon
  • Deep sleep
  • Estrogens and androgens
  • Stressful stimuli

Stimuli that decrease GH secretion:

  • Glucose
  • Cortisol
  • Free fatty acids
  • Growth hormone and IGF-1
  • REM sleep
  • Medroxyprogesterone

GH can act directly on the cells or mediate its actions through insulin-like growth factors (IGF). The functions which are mediated through IGFs are insulin-like activity, anti-lipolytic activity, protein synthesis, and epiphyseal growth. Direct actions of GH are sodium retention, decreased insulin sensitivity, lipolysis, protein synthesis, and epiphyseal growth.

Actions of growth hormone:

  • Growth of cartilage, bones, and organs.
  • Increases amino acid uptake and protein synthesis in the cells and decreases protein breakdown.
  • Diabetogenic action: Increases the hepatic glucose release and decreases the glucose uptake by muscles and fat.
  • Increases fat utilization. It is ketogenic and increases circulating free fatty acid levels.

Since somatostatin inhibits the release of GH, somatostatin analogs like octreotide and lanreotide are used in the treatment of acromegaly.

questions.text: A known amount of inulin and Evans blue dye is injected into a healthy woman of 60 Kgs. The volume of distribution of inulin was found to be 10L and the volume of distribution of Evans blue dye was found to be 2.5L. Which among the following is true regarding the volumes of various body fluids in this woman?
questions.solution:
In this woman, the interstitial fluid volume is 7.5 L.

In the above scenario, the volume of distribution of Evans blue, which measures the volume of plasma is 2.5 L. The volume of distribution of inulin, which measures the extracellular fluid is 10 L. 

Therefore,

Interstitial fluid volume = Extracellular fluid volume - Plasma volume

= 10L- 2.5L

= 7.5 L

Other volumes

About two-thirds of the total body water is present as intracellular fluid and one-third are present as extracellular fluid. Therefore, intracellular fluid will be approximately 2 times the extracellular fluid, which is around 20L. The addition of extracellular fluid with the intracellular fluid will give total body water, that is 20L+ 10L = 30L

The total body fluid is distributed mainly between two compartments, the extracellular fluid, and the intracellular fluid. The intracellular fluid is about two-thirds of the total body water and the extracellular fluid (ECF) is about one-third of the total body water. The ECF is divided into the interstitial fluid and the blood plasma. Interstitial fluid is about three-fourth of the ECF and blood plasma constitutes about one-fourth of ECF.

In an adult man, total body water is 60% of the total body weight whereas, in a woman, the total body water is 50% of the body weight.

  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.

questions.text: You prescribe oral rehydration solution (ORS) to a child brought to the outpatient department with complaints of loose stools. ORS facilitates glucose absorption through sodium-dependent glucose co-transporter-1 (SGLT-1). This glucose co-transport with sodium ions is an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Glucose co-transported with sodium is an example of secondary active transport.

Transporting more than one substance together using a single transport protein against the gradient is known as secondary active transport. As one of the substances (e.g., sodium) diffuses down its electrochemical gradient, energy is released, which is used to drive another substance (e.g., glucose) against the gradient. Thus, secondary active transport does not require energy directly from ATP.
 
Sodium ions are transported out of cells by primary active transport, resulting in a large concentration gradient across the cell membrane. This gradient represents a storehouse of energy, which is used by sodium to pull glucose along with it using the SGLT-1 transporter. This phenomenon, called co- transport, is one form of secondary active transport. 

Types of transport:

  • Active transport
    • Primary
      • Energy is derived from ATP.
      • Example: Na+ K+ ATPase pump.
    • Secondary:
      • Energy is derived indirectly (ion gradient).
      • Example: Sodium linked glucose transport in kidneys and intestine, Sodium linked iodine transport
  • Passive transport
    • Simple:
      • No energy is required.
      • No carrier molecule is involved.
      • Eg. O2 exchange in alveoli.
    • Facilitated:
      • No energy is required.
      • Carrier molecule involved.
      • Eg. Glucose transport by GLUT transporters.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about the myogenic autoregulation of renal blood flow (RBF) and glomerular filtration rate (GFR)?

choices.text: Increased movement of calcium into cells
Increases RBF when arterial pressure rises
Prevents excessive stretch of renal vessels

questions.solution:
The myogenic mechanism of autoregulation helps to prevent excessive rises in renal blood flow and glomerular filtration rate when the arterial pres­sure increases.

The stretch of the vascular wall allows increased movement of calcium ions into the cells from the extracellular fluid. This causes vessel wall contraction preventing excessive stretch of the vessel and raising vascular resistance. This prevents increases in renal blood flow and GFR when the arterial pres­sure increases.

This mechanism is important in protect­ing the kidney from hypertension­-induced injuries. When there is a sudden increase in blood pressure, the myo­genic constrictor response in the afferent arterioles occurs within seconds, reducing the transmission of excessively high arterial pressure to the glomerular capillaries.

questions.text: Inhibition by Renshaw cells is being studied by a physiologist. All of the following are the properties of these cells, except:
questions.solution:
Feedforward inhibition is not a property exhibited by Renshaw cells. 

Renshaw cells are involved in feedback inhibition and lateral inhibition.

Feedback inhibition (Recurrent inhibition): Signals from neurons may inhibit themselves by negative feedback. This is known as feedback inhibition or recurrent inhibition. Signals from a neuron may stimulate the Renshaw cell, which in turn inhibits the same neuron.

Lateral inhibition: Stimulation of one motor neuron inhibits adjacent motor neurons. This is known as lateral inhibition. Signals from the spinal motor neurons stimulate Renshaw cells, which are inhibitory interneurons. Renshaw cells transmit inhibitory signals to the adjacent motor neurons, by releasing the neurotransmitter glycine. This helps in sharpening signals in order to maintain the desired direction of signal transmission. 

Feedforward inhibition: Signals from neurons stimulate inhibitory cells. These inhibitory cells then inhibit a different group of neurons. This is called feedforward inhibition. For example, granule cells stimulate the inhibitory basket cells and stellate cells via parallel fibers. These basket and stellate cells then inhibit the Purkinje cells. This is known as feedforward inhibition.

questions.text: A young patient was operated on for a brain tumor. Following surgery, it is found that there is an injury to the hypothalamus. All of the following anterior pituitary hormones are likely to be decreased in this patient except:
questions.solution:
Following damage to the hypothalamus, all the hormones secreted by the anterior pituitary will decrease except prolactin. 

The hypothalamus plays an important role in controlling the hormones released from the anterior pituitary. It mainly stimulates the production of all the other anterior pituitary hormones except prolactin. It inhibits prolactin production by releasing prolactin inhibitory hormones. 

Therefore, any injury to the hypothalamus or damage to the hypothalamic-hypophysial portal system, the levels of other anterior pituitary hormones are decreased, while the prolactin levels are increased.

Prolactin is secreted by the lactotropes of the anterior pituitary. Structurally it is similar to human growth hormone and human chorionic somatomammotropin (hCS).

Levels of prolactin are increased during exercise, surgical and psychological stresses, stimulation of the nipple, sleep, pregnancy, thyrotropin-releasing hormone, etc.

The important function of prolactin is to cause milk secretion and prevent ovulation in a lactating mother. It increases the production of casein and lactalbumin. Increased prolactin decreases the secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormones, and subsequently decreases the secretion of gonadotropins. 

Clinical correlation - Dopamine released from the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus decreases the secretion of prolactin. Therefore, L dopa which is a precursor of dopamine decreases prolactin secretion, and dopamine antagonists like chlorpromazine and antipsychotics increase the prolactin secretion.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement about pre- Bötzinger complex.

choices.text: Acts as a pacemaker for respiration
Dorsal and ventral respiratory neurons project to it
Located in the nucleus parabrachialis of the pons
Produces discharges in phrenic motor neurons

questions.solution:
The pre- Bötzinger complex (pre-BÖTC) is located on either side of the medulla between the nucleus ambiguus and the lateral reticular nucleus. It is a group of pacemaker cells that initiate rhythmic respiration.

These neurons produce rhythmic discharges in phrenic motor neurons. They are also connected to the hypoglossal nuclei, thus involving the tongue in the regulation of airway resistance. NK1 receptors and μ-opioid receptors are present in these neurons. Substance P stimulates and opioids inhibit respiration.

Dorsal and ventral groups of respiratory neurons (DRG and VRG) are present in the dorsal and ventrolateral portions of the medulla respectively. They have projections on the pre-BÖTC pacemaker neurons. 

  • Dorsal group of respiratory neurons (DRG):
    • Located mainly in the nucleus of the tractus solitarius.
    • This group of neurons emits repetitive bursts of inspiratory neuronal action potentials
  • Ventral group of respiratory neurons (VRG):
    • Located in the nucleus ambiguus rostrally and the nucleus retroambiguus caudally.
    • They provide expiratory signals to the abdominal muscles during very heavy expiration.
    • Acts as overdrive mecha­nism when high levels of pulmonary ventilation are required during heavy exercise
    • May contribute to both inspiration and expiration.

Mnemonic DIVE: Dorsal respiratory group for Inspiration and Ventral respiratory group for Expiration.

The pneumotaxic center is located dorsally in the nucleus parabrachialis of the upper pons. The function of the pneumotaxic center is to limit inspiration. It has a secondary effect of increas­ing the rate of respiration because limitation of inspiration also shortens expiration and the entire period of each respiration.

questions.text: The gastrocolic reflex is mediated by
questions.solution:
The gastrocolic reflex is mediated by prevertebral sympathetic ganglia.

Distension of the stomach and digestive byproducts in the small intestine activate afferents to the prevertebral sympathetic ganglia. This results in stimulation of the colon and an urge to defecate. This is the reason for frequent defecation after meals in children. This reflex can also be amplified by the action of gastrin.

Other reflexes that involve the prevertebral sympathetic ganglia include the following:

  • Enterogastric reflex: Signals from colon and small intestinal signals stop gastric motility and secretion.
  • Colonoileal reflex: Signals from the colon prevent ileal emptying

The brain stem and spinal cord are involved in:

  • Pain reflexes that cause inhibition of the whole gastrointestinal tract
  • Long-distance vagal reflexes regulating gastric motor and secretory activity
  • Defecation reflex: Distension of the rectum and colon results in powerful contractions of the rectum, colon, and abdominal wall.

Local reflexes mediated by the enteric nervous system regulate local secretion, peristalsis, mixing contractions, and ileus.

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, the patient sustained an injury to the right half of the spinal cord. Which of the following features is likely to be seen in this patient below the level of the lesion?

choices.text: Loss of pain and temperature on the right side
Muscle weakness in the left side of the body
Loss of vibration and proprioception on the right side
Loss of vibration and proprioception on the left side

questions.solution:
The feature likely to be seen in this patient below the level of the spinal cord lesion is loss of vibration and proprioception of the right side.

Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown- Séquard syndrome. The features likely to be seen here are - 

  • Ipsilateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion. It occurs as a result of damage to the fasciculus gracilus or fasciculus cuneatus
  • Ipsilateral muscle weakness as a result of damage to the corticospinal tract
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the lesion as a result of damage to the spinothalamic tract.

Corticosteroids administered soon after the injury help in preventing the damage.

Other important syndromes related to the ascending tracts of the spinal cord are

  • Paresthesias are the abnormal sensation of numbness or tingling sensation in the body. It is usually caused due to the irritation of the primary somatosensory cortex.
  • Thalamic pain syndrome is characterized by chronic pain on the side of the body contralateral to the stroke. It occurs during the recovery from the thalamic infarct.

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are true about basal electrical rhythm in the gastrointestinal tract?
  1. They are maximum in the proximal part of the stomach
  2. It is generated by interstitial cells of Cajal
  3. Frequency of these waves in the cecum is 8 per minute
  4. Epinephrine increases the number of spikes and tension
  5. They fluctuate between −65 mV to −45 mV.
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 5 are true regarding basal electrical rhythm in the gastrointestinal system.

Basal electrical rhythm (BER):

The basal electrical rhythm (BER) is a rhythmic fluctuation of membrane potential in the gastrointestinal smooth muscle. The membrane potential fluctuates between -65mV and -45mV. The interstitial cells of Cajal initiate this BER. These cells are stellate mesenchymal pacemaker cells with smooth muscle-like features. In the stomach and small intestine, they are located in the outer circular muscle layer near the myenteric plexus, in the colon, they are at the submucosal border of the circular muscle layer. The BER is seen in all sites of gastrointestinal smooth muscle except in the esophagus and proximal stomach.

The rate of BER in various sites is as follows:

  • Stomach: 4/min
  • Duodenum: 12/min
  • Distal ileum: 8/min
  • Cecum: 2/min
  • Sigmoid colon: 6/min

Spike potentials on BER:

The BER does not cause contraction of the smooth muscle. However, when the BER is superimposed by the spike potentials, it increases muscle tension. The depolarizing portion of each spike is due to Ca2+ influx, and the repolarizing portion is due to K+ efflux. Important neurotransmitters that affect BER are

  • Acetylcholine causes an increase in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.
  • Epinephrine causes a decrease in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.

The function of the BER is to coordinate peristaltic and other motor activity, such as setting the rhythm of segmentation, contractions can occur only during the depolarizing part of the waves. After vagotomy or transection of the stomach wall, for example, peristalsis in the stomach becomes irregular and chaotic.

questions.text: An individual consumed a balanced meal containing carbohydrates, proteins, and fats. Immediately after the meal, assuming that carbohydrates were mainly metabolized, what will the respiratory quotient be?
questions.solution:
The respiratory quotient (RQ) immediately after a balanced meal in which carbohydrates in the food were mainly metabolized will be 1.0.

The respiratory quotient refers to the ratio of carbon dioxide production to oxygen utilization. It estimates the relative utilization of different foods by the body.

Carbohydrates- When carbohydrates are metabolized, one molecule of carbon dioxide is released when one molecule of oxygen is utilized. Therefore, the RQ of carbohydrates is 1. This occurs immediately after a meal when the majority of carbohydrates are metabolized.

Fats- When fats are oxidized, with every 100 molecules of oxygen utilized, an average of 70 carbon dioxide molecules are released. The RQ of fat is therefore 0.70. This happens because when oxygen reacts with fats, a large amount of it combines with hydrogen from the fats, forming water instead of carbon dioxide. Around 8-10 hours after a meal the carbohydrate stores are depleted and fats are utilized. The RQ becomes 0.70. In severe untreated diabetes, carbohydrates are not utilized as they require insulin. Hence, the RQ remains near that of fat metabolism, i.e., 0.70.

Proteins- When proteins are oxidized, with every 100 molecules of oxygen utilized, an average of 80 carbon dioxide molecules are released. Therefore, the RQ of proteins is 0.8. Protein utilization is better estimated by measuring nitrogen excretion. The average protein contains about 16% nitrogen. During the metabolism of the protein, most of the nitrogen is excreted as urea, uric acid, creatinine, and other nitrogen products in the urine and around 10% is excreted in the feces. The utilization of proteins mainly occurs during starvation, when the carbohydrate and the fat stores have been depleted.

questions.text: An individual takes a deep breath of 100% oxygen from mid-inspiration and then expires through a rapidly recording nitrogen meter. This produces the recording shown in the image below. What does this test measure?
questions.solution:
The test described is the single-breath N2 test which is used to measure the dead space volume, and the image shown is the single-breath N2 curve.

From mid-inspiration, the patient inhales 100% oxygen as deeply as possible, then exhales steadily while the N2 content of the expired gas is continuously measured using a nitrogen meter. The recording obtained is the single-breath N2 curve.

  • Phase I of the curve: Initial gas exhaled that was present in the dead space. It does not contain any N2.
  • Phase II: A mixture of dead space and alveolar gas
  • Phase III: Alveolar gas. It terminates at the closing volume (the lung volume above residual volume at which lower airways begin to close due to lesser transmural pressure)
  • Phase IV: The N2 content of the expired gas is increased.

The volume of the dead space is the volume of the gas that is expired from peak inspiration to the midportion of phase II. The total dead space can be calculated using Bohr's equation. 

The anatomic dead space refers to the respiratory system volume exclusive of alveoli, and the total (physiological) dead space is the volume of gas not equilibrating with blood i.,e. wasted ventilation. In healthy individuals, the two dead spaces are almost equal and can be estimated by body weight. The normal dead space air in a young adult man is around 150 mL.

Other options - 

Option B: Forced vital capacity, a dynamic lung measurement from spirometry is the largest amount of air that can be expired after a maximal inspiratory effort. Forced expiratory volume in the first second, FEV1, is the fraction of the vital capacity that is expired during the first second.

 

Option C: Tidal volume (TV) is measured with the help of a diagnostic spirometer. It is the amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration or the amount of air that moves out with each expiration during quiet breathing. The normal values are 500-750 mL.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about this posture?

choices.text: Due to damage in the upper pons

questions.solution:
The image shows decerebrate rigidity, in which there is reticulospinal excitation resulting in hyperactivity of extensor muscles. It occurs due to damage in the upper pons and lower midbrain.

Decerebrate posturing occurs when there is complete transection of the brain stem between the superior and inferior colliculus. The inputs from the corticospinal tract, corticobulbar tract, rubrospinal tract are interrupted, and only the reticulospinal pathway remains intact. Excitatory inputs from the reticulospinal tract stimulate gamma motor neurons which in turn stimulates alpha motor neurons. This results in the contraction of the extensor muscles in the extremities. It can also be seen following uncal herniation.

Injury to the cerebral cortex and upper mid brain produces decorticate rigidity. Here the rubrospinal and the reticulospinal tracts are intact. The excitation of the rubrospinal tract causes flexion of the upper limbs while the excitation of the reticulospinal tract causes extension of the lower extremities.

questions.text: An elderly man with gynecomastia was explained that the condition is due to an imbalance between estrogen and androgens. Which of the following is not a site of estrogen production in males?
questions.solution:
Estrogen in males is not formed in the seminiferous tubules. It comes from Leydig cells, Sertoli cells, and the liver.

Sources of estrogen in men are:

  • Extragonadal and extra-adrenal aromatization of circulating testosterone and androstenedione, especially in the liver, is the major source of estrogen in men.
  • Leydig cells
  • Sertoli cells

Estrogen

Naturally occurring estrogens are estradiol, estrone, and estriol. The major source of estrogen in females is granulosa cells of the ovarian follicles, the corpus luteum, and the placenta. Some amount of estrogen is produced by the aromatization of testosterone and androstenedione in the fat, liver, muscle, and brain.

Important effects of estrogen are:

  • It facilitates the growth of ovarian follicles and increases the motility of uterine tubes.
  • It causes proliferative changes in the endometrium.
  • The secretion of the cervix becomes thin under the influence of estrogen. The mucus is thinnest at the time of ovulation. During the mid-cycle, a drop of cervical secretion can be stretched to 8-12 cm long. This is called the spinnbarkeit phenomenon.
  • It causes the proliferation of mammary ducts.
  • It is responsible for the narrow shoulders, broad hips, and a wide carrying angle in females.

questions.text: An athlete is participating in the Olympics 2023 for 200m swimming. Which of the following energy sources are mainly used by him?
questions.solution:
Glycogen–lactic acid and aerobic systems will be used by the muscles in a 200m swim. 

Energy sources to the muscles can be from different sources:

  • Adenosine triphosphate- Energy released during the cleavage of high-energy phosphate bonds can be utilized by the muscles. This energy derived is sufficient to sustain the actions of muscles for 3 seconds. This is enough for a 50m dash.
  • Phosphocreatine- Phosphocreatine is another molecule that contains high-energy phosphate bonds. It can be cleaved into creatine and phosphate. The energy released from these sources is sufficient to sustain the action of muscles for 8-10s or a 100m run.
  • Glycogen-lactic acid system- The glycogen stored in the muscle can be converted to glucose and this glucose can be utilized to release energy. It can provide energy to the muscle for 1.3-1.6 minutes. 
  • Aerobic system- The energy is derived mainly from the oxidation of glucose, fatty acids, and amino acids. It can provide energy as long as the nutrients last.

The Phosphagen system produces 4 moles of ATP per minute, the glycogen lactic acid system produces 2.5 moles of ATP per minute, and the aerobic system produces 1 mole of ATP per minute.
